case_name: M/s. Daulatram Rameshwarlal v. Sales Tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 45 and 46 of 1959 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 45 and 46 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 25, 1957, of the former Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 16 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 25, 1957, of the former Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 16 of 1957.

facts.text: Ms. Daulatram Rameshwarlal is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act and registered dealers under s. 11 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-M s. Daulatram Rameshwarlal, a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act  referred to later in this judgment as sellers   are registered dealers under s. 11 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Sellers claimed exemption from Sales Tax for sales of cotton worth Rs. 68,493-2-6 and castor oil worth Rs. 6,47,509-1-6 for period April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955, on ground of FOB contracts.

anchor.surface_text: In their return of turnover for the period from April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955, they claimed exemption from Sales Tax in respect of sales of companyton of the total value of Rs. 68,493-2-6 and sales of castor oil of the total value of Rs. 6,47,509-1-6 on the ground that these sales were oil FOB companytracts,

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer rejected the exemption claim and assessed sales tax on those sales.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer rejected this claim for exemption and assessed them to sales tax on a taxable turnover including these sales.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer assessed purchase tax under s. 10 b on purchase of castor oil sold for Rs. 6,47,509-1-6.

anchor.surface_text: He also assessed them to purchase tax under s. 10 b  of the Bombay Sales Tax Act on their purchase of castor oil which they later sold for the sum of Rs. 6,47,509-1-6 as mentioned above.

facts.text: Notice of demand for sales tax and purchase tax served on sellers on September 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice of demand for the total sales tax and the purchase tax assessed was served on the sellers on September 30, 1956.

facts.text: Sellers filed petition under Art. 226 in Bombay High Court to quash assessment and notice.

anchor.surface_text: The sellers thereupon moved the Bombay High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitu- tion for the issue of appropriate writs for quashing the order of assessment and the numberice of demand and for prohibiting the Sales Tax Officer from taking any steps pursuant to the order or the numberice.

facts.text: Single Judge of Bombay HC rejected sellers' contentions on sales tax exemption and purchase tax.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who heard the petition rejected the sellers companytention that the goods remained their property till these crossed the customs frontier and therefore held that the sellers were number entitled to the benefit of Art. 286 1  b  of the Constitution. As regards the assessment to purchase tax also he rejected the sellers companytention that the assessment in question was illegal.

facts.text: Bombay HC Division Bench held sales exempted under Art. 286(1)(b) as property passed on shipment, but upheld purchase tax liability.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges who heard the appeal held, disagreeing with the Trial Judge, that the goods remained the sellers property till the goods had been brought on board the ship and so the sales were exempted from tax under Art. 286 1  b  of the Constitution. They however agreed with the Trial Judger that the sellers were liable to pay purchase tax under s. 10 b  of the Bombay Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Division Bench directed Sales Tax Officer not to enforce sales tax demand on cotton and castor oil sales.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly they directed the Sales Tax Officer number to enforce the demand for payment of sales tax with regard to the sales of companyton for Rs. 68,493-2-6 and sale of castor oil of the total value of Rs. 6,47,509-1-6.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer preferred Civil Appeal No. 45 of 1959 against HC order on sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer has, on the strength of special leave granted by this Court, preferred the appeal which has been numbered as Civil Appeal No. 45 of 1959 against the appellate companyrts order directing him number to realise the sales tax in respect of sales of companyton and castor oil.

facts.text: Sellers preferred Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1959 against HC judgment upholding purchase tax.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1959 has been preferred by the sellers against the appellate companyrts judgment in so far as it upheld the assessment of purchase tax under s. 10 b .

facts.text: Sales were under FOB contracts, not denied by Sales Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The sellers case is that these were sales on FOB companytracts. Though the learned Solicitor-General appearing on behalf of the Sales Tax Officer tried to companyvince us that these were number really FOB companytract sales, it appears that the averment in Paras. 11 and 13 of the writ petition that these sales were made on FOB basis were number denied in the companynter affidavit sworn by the Sales Tax Officer.

facts.text: In FOB contracts, property passes on shipment of goods.

anchor.surface_text: The numbermal rule in FOB companytracts is that the property is intended to pass and does pass on the shipment of the goods.

facts.text: Bill of lading taken in name of buyer but retained by sellers until payment on presentation of documents.

anchor.surface_text: The first circumstance on which he relies is that the bill of lading was taken in the name of the buyer. Along with this fact we have to companysider however the fact that the bill of lading was retained by the sellers, the companytract being that payment will be made on the presentation of the bill of lading.

facts.text: Export under buyer's export licence.

anchor.surface_text: The second circumstance to which our attention has been drawn is that the export was under the companytract to be under the buyers export licence.

facts.text: Export Control Order, 1954, clause 5(2) deems goods to be property of licensee at time of export.

anchor.surface_text: The third circumstance on which reliance is placed on behalf of the Sales Tax Officer is that the Export Control Order, 1954, which was passed in the exercise of powers companyferred by Import Export Control Act, 1947, companytained a provision in its clause 5 2  in these words- It shall be deemed to be a companydition of that licence that the goods for the export of which licence is granted shall be the property of the licensee at the time of the export .

facts.text: Supreme Court held property in goods passed on shipment, after customs frontier, sales in course of export, exempted under Art. 286(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: We think that the learned judges who heard the appeal in the Bombay High Court were right in their companyclusion that the goods remained the sellers property till the goods had been brought and loaded on board the ship and so the sales were exempted from tax under Art. 286 1  b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Certificate under s.8(b) furnished by sellers for castor oil purchases, sellers of castor oil allowed deductions.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly such a certificate was furnished by M s. Daulatram Rameshwarlal in respect of the castor oil which they sold to others and that in respect of these sales to them their sellers were allowed deductions.

facts.text: Goods sold by sellers to persons who are not registered dealers, who despatched goods outside Bombay within 6 months.

anchor.surface_text: It is equally undisputed that the persons to whom M s. Daulatram Rameshwarlal sold the goods were sent to an address outside the State of Bombay within a period of six months from the date of purchase by M s. Daulatram Rameshwarlal. These persons are however number registered dealers.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld purchase tax under s.10(b) as 'person' means registered dealer.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that the companyrts below have rightly interpreted the words a person in s. 10 b  of the Bombay Sales Tax Act as a registered dealer and that the purchasing dealers have rightly been assessed to purchase tax under s. 10 b .

issues.text: The only question for our decision in the appeal by the Sales Tax Officer is whether property in the goods passed on shipment or at some point of time before shipment.

anchor.surface_text: The only question for our decision in the appeal by the Sales Tax Officer is whether property in the goods passed on shipment or at some point of time before shipment.

issues.text: Whether on a correct interpretation of the provisions of s. 10 b of the Bombay Sales Tax Act no purchase tax was leviable from the sellers, or whether 'a person' in s. 10 b means a registered dealer.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1959 the appellants contention is that on a correct interpretation of the provisions of s. 10 b of the Bombay Sales Tax Act no purchase tax was leviable from them. Section 10 b provides for the levy

arguments.claim: Sales of cotton and castor oil exempt from sales tax under Art. 286(1)(b) as FOB contracts where sellers remained owners till goods crossed customs barrier and entered export stream

anchor.surface_text: In their return of turnover for the period from April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955, they claimed exemption from Sales Tax in respect of sales of cotton of the total value of Rs. 68,493-2-6 and sales of castor oil of the total value of Rs. 6,47,509-1-6 on the ground that these sales were on FOB contracts, under which they continued to be the owners of the goods till the goods had crossed the customs barrier and thus entered the export stream, and so no tax was realisable on these sales in view of the provisions of Art. 286 (1) (b ).

The question whether there was such a different agreement has to be decided on a consideration of all the surrounding circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the United Motors Case and in other cases it has been held by this Court that the course of export commences to run when the goods cross the customs barrier... We have therefore come to the conclusion that there is no circumstance which would justify a conclusion that the parties came to a special agreement that though the sales were on FOB contracts property in the goods would pass to the buyer at some point of time before shipment.

arguments.claim: Purchase tax not leviable under s.10(b); 'a person' includes unregistered dealer who despatches goods outside state

anchor.surface_text: It is contended before us on behalf of the appellant-dealers that the word a person is wide enough to include a registered dealer and an unregistered dealer. It is urged that the use of the word a person instead of the words a registered dealer is deliberate and that it was the intention of the Legislature to levy purchase tax on a person who has given such certificate under s. 8(b) only if the goods were not despatched outside the State of Bombay within the prescribed period by anybody.

holdings.text: The goods remained the sellers' property till the goods had been brought and loaded on board the ship and so the sales were exempted from tax under Art. 286(1)(b) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the learned judges who heard the appeal in the Bombay High Court were right in their conclusion that the goods remained the sellers property till the goods had been brought and loaded on board the ship and so the sales were exempted from tax under Art. 286 1 b of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: FOB contracts; property passes on shipment unless special agreement shown by circumstances; bill of lading retained by sellers until payment, export licence is buyer's duty under FOB presumption, 'time of export' in Export Control Order cl.5(2) is when ship leaves port or territorial waters (not customs frontier), distinguishing course of export precedents under Art.286.

holdings.text: The courts below have rightly interpreted the words 'a person' in s. 10(b) of the Bombay Sales Tax Act as a registered dealer and the purchasing dealers have rightly been assessed to purchase tax under s. 10(b).

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion therefore is that the courts below have rightly interpreted the words a person in s. 10 b of the Bombay Sales Tax Act as a registered dealer and that the purchasing dealers have rightly been assessed to purchase tax under s. 10 b .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of ss.8(b) and 10(b): certificate declares intention for despatch by self or registered dealer to whom sold; must be carried out by registered dealer; despatch by non-registered person does not fulfil declared intention, attracting purchase tax levy.

Pound  2  the Court of Appeal in England held that the judgment in Brandts case  1  does number companyer every FOB companytract and that in the special facts of the particular case before them it was for the sellers to obtain the licence and this view was approved by the House of Lords 1956 A. C. 588 , it is in our opinion companyrect to state that the presumption in FOB companytracts is that it is the duty of the buyers to obtain export licence, though in the circumstances of a particular case this duty may fall on the sellers.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the United Motor8 Case  1  and in other cases it has been held by this Court that the course of export commences to run when the goods cross the customs barrier. What the court had to consider in these cases was no however when export commences within the meaning of the Exports Control Order but when the course of export commences for the purpose of Art. 286 1  b  of the Constitution.

precedents.cited_proposition: course of export commences to run when the goods cross the customs barrier

anchor.surface_text: the time  1  1917 2 K.B. 784.  2  1955 1 Q.B. 499. when the goods cross the customs frontier. Export has been defined in the Import Export Control Act, 1947, as taking out of India by sea, land or air . In the Exports Control Order, 1954, the word must be taken to have the same meaning as in the Act. On that definition the time of the export is the time when the goods go out of the territorial limits of India.
